dialogs.original: Well, I had rather than twice the worth of her shehad ne'er come here.
dialogs.translated: I don't care what she's worth; I wish she had never come here.

dialogs.original: Fie, fie upon her! she's able to freeze the god    Priapus, and undo a whole generation.   We must    either get her ravished, or be rid of her.   When she    should do for clients her fitment, and do me the    kindness of our profession, she has me her quirks,    her reasons, her master reasons, her prayers, her    knees;     that she would make a puritan of the devil,    if he should cheapen a kiss of her.
dialogs.translated: Shame, shame on her! She could convince even the most hot-blooded man not to have sex. We either need to have someone sleep with her or get rid of her. When she's supposed to be fulfilling her customers' desires (and giving me the profit), instead she's up to all her shenanigans: her excuses, her better excuses, her prayers, begging on her knees. She could turn the devil himself into a born-again Christian if he so much as tried to kiss her.

dialogs.original: 'Faith, I must ravish her, or she'll disfurnish usof all our cavaliers, and make our swearers priests.
dialogs.translated: Well, I'll have to rape her, or she'll ruin all our customers, converting the evil-doers to good.

dialogs.original: Now, the pox upon her green-sickness for me!
dialogs.translated: Damn her inexperience!

dialogs.original: 'Faith, there's no way to be rid on't but by theway to the pox. Here comes the Lord Lysimachus disguised.
dialogs.translated: Well, there's no way for her to get experience except by getting experience.  Here comes Lord Lysimachus in a disguise.

dialogs.original: We should have both lord and lown, if the peevishbaggage would but give way to customers.
dialogs.translated: We could win him and his money over if the girl would just give in to customers.

dialogs.original: How now! How a dozen of virginities?
dialogs.translated: Hello! How much for a dozen virginities?

dialogs.original: Now, the gods to-bless your honour!
dialogs.translated: God bless you, sir.

dialogs.original: I am glad to see your honour in good health.
dialogs.translated: I'm glad to see you're healthy, sir.

dialogs.original: You may so; 'tis the better for you that your    resorters stand upon sound legs.   How now!    wholesome iniquity have you that a man may deal    withal, and defy the surgeon?
dialogs.translated: I'm sure you areit's better for your business when your clients keep from getting sick! What new stock do you have here that might allow a man to enjoy his whores and keep the sexually-transmitted diseases at bay?

dialogs.original: We have here one, sir, if she wouldbut there nevercame her like in Mytilene.
dialogs.translated: We have one here, sir, if she would . . . but we've never had anyone like her in Mytilene.

dialogs.original: If she'ld do the deed of darkness, thou wouldst say.
dialogs.translated: If she would do the dirty, you mean.

dialogs.original: Your honour knows what 'tis to say well enough.
dialogs.translated: You're exactly right, sir.

dialogs.original: Well, call forth, call forth.
dialogs.translated: Well, bring her in, then!

dialogs.original: For flesh and blood, sir, white and red, you shallsee a rose; and she were a rose indeed, if she had but
dialogs.translated: Sir, it might be better if someone else popped the cherry before you

dialogs.original: What, prithee?
dialogs.translated: What did you say?

dialogs.original: O, sir, I can be modest.
dialogs.translated: Oh, sir, I can be quiet.

dialogs.original: That dignifies the renown of a bawd, no less than itgives a good report to a number to be chaste.
dialogs.translated: Silence is as useful to a bawd as a reputation is to a virgin.

dialogs.original: Here comes that which grows to the stalk; neverplucked yet, I can assure you.
dialogs.translated: Here comes a fresh flower. Never been picked, I can assure you.

dialogs.original: Is she not a fair creature?
dialogs.translated: Isn't she pretty?

dialogs.original: 'Faith, she would serve after a long voyage at sea.Well, there's for you: leave us.
dialogs.translated: She's just what you want after a long voyage at sea. [He gives the BAWD a coin] Well, there you go. Leave us.

dialogs.original: I beseech your honour, give me leave: a word, andI'll have done presently.
dialogs.translated: Please, sir, let me speak with her first and then I'll leave you.

dialogs.original: I beseech you, do.
dialogs.translated: Please, do.

dialogs.original: [To MARINA]  First, I would have you note, this isan honourable man.
dialogs.translated: [To MARINA] First, please note that he is an honorable man.

dialogs.original: I desire to find him so, that I may worthily note him.
dialogs.translated: I hope he proves himself so; then I can respect him.

dialogs.original: Next, he's the governor of this country, and a manwhom I am bound to.
dialogs.translated: Second: he's the governor of this country, and I'm bound to serve him.

dialogs.original: If he govern the country, you are bound to himindeed; but how honourable he is in that, I know not.
dialogs.translated: If he governs the country, you are definitely bound to serve him. It's unclear how honorable he is in the act of governing, though.

dialogs.original: Pray you, without any more virginal fencing, willyou use him kindly? He will line your apron with gold.
dialogs.translated: Please stop arguing with me. Will you do him well? He'll give you a lot of money.

dialogs.original: What he will do graciously, I will thankfully receive.
dialogs.translated: Whatever he gives courteously, I accept gratefully.

dialogs.original: Ha' you done?
dialogs.translated: Are you done?

dialogs.original: My lord, she's not paced yet: you must take somepains to work her to your manage. Come, we willleave his honour and her together. Go thy ways.
dialogs.translated: Sir, she hasn't been broken in yet; you'll need to work hard to make her obey. [To BOULT and PANDAR] Come on, we'll leave the two of them together. Go on, now.

dialogs.original: Now, pretty one, how long have you been at this trade?
dialogs.translated: So, pretty girl, how long have you been working in this business?

dialogs.original: What trade, sir?
dialogs.translated: What business, sir?

dialogs.original: Why, I cannot name't but I shall offend.
dialogs.translated: I can't say the name, or I'll offend you.

dialogs.original: I cannot be offended with my trade. Please you to name it.
dialogs.translated: I can't be offended by the name of my business. Please say it.

dialogs.original: How long have you been of this profession?
dialogs.translated: How long have you been in this profession?

dialogs.original: E'er since I can remember.
dialogs.translated: Ever since I can remember.

dialogs.original: Did you go to 't so young? Were you a gamester atfive or at seven?
dialogs.translated: Did you start that young? Were you a prostitute at the age of five or seven?

dialogs.original: Earlier too, sir, if now I be one.
dialogs.translated: Earlier that that, sir, if that's what I am now.

dialogs.original: Why, the house you dwell in proclaims you to be acreature of sale.
dialogs.translated: The place where you live proclaims you to be a prostitute.

dialogs.original: Do you know this house to be a place of such resort,and will come into 't? I hear say you are ofhonourable parts, and are the governor of this place.
dialogs.translated: If you know this place is a brothel, why did you come in? I've heard that you're honorable, and that you're the governor of this place.

dialogs.original: Why, hath your principal made known unto you who I am?
dialogs.translated: Did your boss tell you who I am?

dialogs.original: Who is my principal?
dialogs.translated: Who is my boss?

dialogs.original: Why, your herb-woman; she that sets seeds and roots    of shame and iniquity.   O, you have heard something    of my power, and so stand aloof for more serious    wooing.   But I protest to thee, pretty one, my    authority shall not see thee, or else look friendly    upon thee.   Come, bring me to some private place:    come, come.
dialogs.translated: The Bawd, the one that teaches you and facilitates your shame and wickedness. All right, you've heard I'm powerful  and rich so you're playing hard to get. I'll have you know, pretty girl, that once I see you, I'll pay you very well. Come on, bring me to a private room. Come, come.

dialogs.original: If you were born to honour, show it now;    If put upon you, make the judgment good    That thought you worthy of it.
dialogs.translated: If you were born to power, sir, prove how honorable you are now. If you rose to power later, prove that those who thought you were honorable then made a good choice.

dialogs.original: How's this? how's this? Some more; be sage.
dialogs.translated: What? What? Say more, be clear.

dialogs.original: For me,    That am a maid, though most ungentle fortune    Have placed me in this sty, where, since I came,    Diseases have been sold dearer than physic,    O, that the gods    Would set me free from this unhallow'd place,    Though they did change me to the meanest bird    That flies i' the purer air!
dialogs.translated: I'm a virgin, although bad luck has landed me in this dump where, since I came people have paid more to get diseases than they would for medicine. Oh, may the gods set me free from this hellish place, even if it means changing me into a bird that flies through the pure air!

dialogs.original: I did not think    Thou couldst have spoke so well; ne'er dream'd thou couldst.    Had I brought hither a corrupted mind,    Thy speech had alter'd it.   Hold, here's gold for thee:    Persever in that clear way thou goest,    And the gods strengthen thee!
dialogs.translated: I couldn't have imagined you could speak so well; I couldn't have dreamed it. If I had had a dirty mind, your speech would have changed it. Here, take this coin. Keep going on this virtuous path, and may the gods bless you!

dialogs.original: The good gods preserve you!
dialogs.translated: May the gods protect you!

dialogs.original: For me, be you thoughten    That I came with no ill intent; for to me    The very doors and windows savour vilely.    Fare thee well. Thou art a piece of virtue, and    I doubt not but thy training hath been noble.    Hold, here's more gold for thee.    A curse upon him, die he like a thief,    That robs thee of thy goodness!   If thou dost    Hear from me, it shall be for thy good.
dialogs.translated: As for me: rest assured I had no bad intentions. Actually, this whole place is disgusting. Goodbye. You are virtuous, and I have no doubt that you've had an aristocratic education. Here, here's more gold for you. Curse anyone who tries to force himself on you, may he die like a thief! If you ever hear from me again, it'll be for your benefit.

dialogs.original: I beseech your honour, one piece for me.
dialogs.translated: Please, sir, a coin for me?

dialogs.original: Avaunt, thou damned door-keeper!Your house, but for this virgin that doth prop it,Would sink and overwhelm you. Away!
dialogs.translated: Get out, you damned doorman! Without this virgin keeping it up, this whole house would collapse and bury you! Away!

dialogs.original: How's this? We must take another course with you.    If your peevish chastity, which is not worth a    breakfast in the cheapest country under the cope,    shall undo a whole household,   let me be gelded like    a spaniel. Come your ways.
dialogs.translated: What now? We'll have to try a different tactic with you. Your worthless virginitywhich isn't worth a cheap breakfast eaten in the nightisn't about to ruin this place; I'd rather be neutered like a dog than see that happen. Come with me.

dialogs.original: Whither would you have me?
dialogs.translated: Where are you taking me?

dialogs.original: I must have your maidenhead taken off, or the common    hangman shall execute it.   Come your ways. We'll    have no more gentlemen driven away. Come your ways, I say.
dialogs.translated: I have to deflower you; otherwise you'll have to be killed. Come with me. We can't have any more gentleman driven away. Come with me, I said!

dialogs.original: How now! what's the matter?
dialogs.translated: Hey, what's going on here?

dialogs.original: Worse and worse, mistress; she has here spoken holywords to the Lord Lysimachus.
dialogs.translated: Worse and worse, ma'am. She's preached some sermon to Lord Lysimachus.

dialogs.original: O abominable!
dialogs.translated: It's unthinkable!

dialogs.original: She makes our profession as it were to stink aforethe face of the gods.
dialogs.translated: She's ruining the name of our profession.

dialogs.original: Marry, hang her up for ever!
dialogs.translated: For goodness' sake, have her hanged!

dialogs.original: The nobleman would have dealt with her like anobleman, and she sent him away as cold as asnowball; saying his prayers too.
dialogs.translated: The nobleman would have done with her what a nobleman does, but she sent him away as cold as a snowball, and saying his prayers, too.

dialogs.original: Boult, take her away; use her at thy pleasure:crack the glass of her virginity, and make the rest malleable.
dialogs.translated: Boult, take her away. Do whatever you like with her. Smash her virginity into pieces so we can mold the rest into whatever shape we want.

dialogs.original: An if she were a thornier piece of ground than sheis, she shall be ploughed.
dialogs.translated: Even if she were uglier than she is, she'd have to be screwed.

dialogs.original: Hark, hark, you gods!
dialogs.translated: Gods, listen, help me!

dialogs.original: She conjures: away with her! Would she had never    come within my doors! Marry, hang you! She's born    to undo us.   Will you not go the way of women-kind?    Marry, come up, my dish of chastity with rosemary and bays!
dialogs.translated: She's praying; take her away! I wish she had never set foot in this house. Damn her! She's going to ruin us. Don't you want to do what women do? Come up, my little virgin pie with rosemary and bay leaves!

dialogs.original: Come, mistress; come your ways with me.
dialogs.translated: Come on, missy, come with me.

dialogs.original: Whither wilt thou have me?
dialogs.translated: What are you going to do to me?

dialogs.original: To take from you the jewel you hold so dear.
dialogs.translated: Take away your most prized possession.

dialogs.original: Prithee, tell me one thing first.
dialogs.translated: Please, tell me one thing first.

dialogs.original: Come now, your one thing.
dialogs.translated: All right, what's your one thing?

dialogs.original: What canst thou wish thine enemy to be?
dialogs.translated: Who's the worst person you know?

dialogs.original: Why, I could wish him to be my master, or rather, my mistress.
dialogs.translated: Probably the Pandar. Or the Bawd.

dialogs.original: Neither of these are so bad as thou art,    Since they do better thee in their command.    Thou hold'st a place, for which the pained'st fiend    Of hell would not in reputation change:    Thou art the damned doorkeeper to every    Coistrel that comes inquiring for his Tib;    To the choleric fisting of every rogue    Thy ear is liable; thy food is such    As hath been belch'd on by infected lungs.
dialogs.translated: Neither of them is as bad as you; their jobs are better than yours. The worst demon in hell wouldn't trade places with you. You're the damned doorman who lets in every vagabond that comes looking for his slut; every diseased person owes his misery to you. The very food you eat has been burped on by infected lungs.

dialogs.original: What would you have me do? go to the wars, would    you?   where a man may serve seven years for the loss    of a leg, and have not money enough in the end to    buy him a wooden one?
dialogs.translated: What do you want me to do? Fight in the war, huh? Where a man might serve seven years before he loses a leg, and then not have enough money to buy a wooden one?

dialogs.original: Do any thing but this thou doest. Empty    Old receptacles, or common shores, of filth;    Serve by indenture to the common hangman:    Any of these ways are yet better than this;    For what thou professest, a baboon, could he speak,    Would own a name too dear.   O, that the gods    Would safely deliver me from this place!    Here, here's gold for thee.    If that thy master would gain by thee,    Proclaim that I can sing, weave, sew, and dance,    With other virtues, which I'll keep from boast:    And I will undertake all these to teach.    I doubt not but this populous city will    Yield many scholars.
dialogs.translated: Do anything but this. Empty trash cans, or clean up the beaches. Work as an apprentice in the prison. Anything is better than this. What you do? If a baboon could speak, he would say your job is beneath him. I wish the gods would take me out of here safely! Here, take this gold coin. If your master is intent to make a profit from me, let him know I can sing, weave, sew, and dance, and more which I won't brag about. I'll hire myself out to teach all these. I have no doubt that I'll find plenty of students in the city.

dialogs.original: But can you teach all this you speak of?
dialogs.translated: Can you teach all those things?

dialogs.original: Prove that I cannot, take me home again,And prostitute me to the basest groomThat doth frequent your house.
dialogs.translated: If it turns out that I can't, you can take me home and prostitute me to the lowest peasant that's a regular at your house.

dialogs.original: Well, I will see what I can do for thee: if I canplace thee, I will.
dialogs.translated: Well, I'll see what I can do for you. If I can help you, I will.

dialogs.original: But amongst honest women.
dialogs.translated: I want to work among honest women.

dialogs.original: 'Faith, my acquaintance lies little amongst them.    But since my master and mistress have bought you,    there's no going but by their consent:   therefore I    will make them acquainted with your purpose, and I    doubt not but I shall find them tractable enough.    Come, I'll do for thee what I can; come your ways.
dialogs.translated: I don't know many of them, I'll tell you. But since my master and mistress have bought you, there's no way of going unless they consent. So I'll explain your plan to them; I'm sure they'll be willing. Come on, I'll do what I can for you. Come with me.
